I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
programmatic approach for the Financial Market Development Program, and (ii) a proposed 
policy-based  loan  to  the  Kingdom  of  Bhutan  for  subprogram  1  of  the  Financial  Market 
Development  Program.  The  report  also  describes  proposed  technical  assistance  (TA)  for 
Supporting the Financial Market Development Program, and if the Board approves the proposed 
loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, approve the TA. 
 
2.  The program supports key policy reforms designed to address identified deficiencies, 
vulnerabilities, and inadequate inclusiveness in the finance sector, while drawing lessons from 
previous programs of the Asian Development Bank (ADB).1 The program aims to strengthen the 
finance sector’s resource mobilization to improve its allocative efficiency and to enhance stability 
and inclusiveness at the request of the Government of Bhutan. The program is included in ADB’s 
country operations business plan, 2019–2021 for commitment in 2019.2 
 
II.  PROGRAM AND RATIONALE 
 
A.  Background and Development Constraints 
 
3.  Development problem. There are several emerging priorities facing the government after 
3 decades of rapid economic growth—which averaged 7.0% from fiscal year (FY) 1998 to 
FY2018—and a reduction in the national poverty rate from 23.0% in 2007 to 8.2% in 2017. 
Hydropower has been the main driver of economic growth, contributing about 25.0% to gross 
domestic product annually. However, the capital-intensive nature of hydropower has restricted 
the  industry’s  ability  to  create  adequate  employment  opportunities  for  the  growing  youth 
population entering the labor market. Therefore, the government’s Twelfth Five Year Plan, 2018–
2023 aims to diversify the economy by creating jobs and promoting the private sector.3 The 
relatively small private sector is comprised mainly of micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises. 
Inadequate access to finance and the high cost of obtaining credit are among the principal 
constraints to private sector development.4 
 
4.  As Bhutan is set to graduate from the United Nations list of least-developed countries in 
2023, the country consequently will have less access to concessionary resources. Currently, 
domestic  savings  finances  only  66%  of  the  annual  budget.  The  government  finances  the 
remaining  34%  through  external  loans  and  official  development  assistance.  Therefore,  the 
government will need to mobilize greater domestic resources by promoting private savings and 
investments to compensate for its diminishing access to concessionary resources.

5.  Binding constraints. The government recognizes that the finance sector plays a critical 
role in mobilizing domestic resources to meet development needs. Concurrently, the government 
has resolved to allocate sufficient resources to promote private sector development efficiently. 
There are three key binding constraints on the finance sector: (i) underdeveloped nonbank 
financial institutions, (ii) deficient financial infrastructure, and (iii) the combined effects of low 
financial literacy and inadequate financial inclusion. 
 
6.  Underdeveloped  nonbank  financial  institutions.  The  banking  sector  dominates 
Bhutan’s financial system. It provided 87% of total finance sector assets as of December 2018. 
The banking sector’s deposit base is predominantly short term, but its loans are typically long 
term. This creates maturity mismatches and a liquidity risk, which were among the major causes 
of the Asian financial crisis. Inadequate long-term sources of finance and, consequently, limited 
long-term investments restrict the development of the finance sector. The capital market, including 
the government debt market, remains shallow. There is no long-term domestic government bond, 
and the corporate bond market is highly illiquid. The Royal Securities Exchange of Bhutan (RSEB) 
has registered total outstanding corporate bonds worth Nu8.76 billion (about $123 million) against 
17 bonds listed on the RSEB. In 2018, companies in Bhutan issued four commercial papers worth 
Nu3.75 billion (about $53 million). As of April 2019, the total market capitalization on the RSEB 
stood at Nu44.71 billion (about $627 million), with 21 listed companies and 6 brokerage firms. 
Currently, such investors as the National Pension and Provident Fund (NPPF) and insurance 
companies concentrate their investments in a very limited class of assets. The government has 
yet to establish risk-based rules and regulations to supervise the solvency of insurers and the 
sustainability of pensions. In addition, financial institutions in Bhutan are unable to meet domestic 
housing finance demands. In response to a surge in demand for housing, especially around the 
suburbs of Bhutan’s largest cities—Thimphu, Phuentsholing, and Paro—banks had been lending 
heavily for housing before the Indian rupee crisis of 2012.5 Housing loans then comprised 25% of 
total finance sector credit and posed a risk of overconcentration. Because banks generally provide 
20-year fixed-rate housing loans, they are vulnerable to a rise in interest rates.6 According to the 
Bhutan  Living  Standards  Survey  Report  2017,  middle-income  and  lower-income  urban 
households spend an estimated 40%‒60% of their disposable income on rent because of lack of 
affordable housing.7 
 
7.  Deficient financial infrastructure. Bhutan’s financial system is potentially vulnerable to 
rapid changes in the global financial landscape. In its 2016 mutual evaluation report on Bhutan, 
the Asia/Pacific Group on Money Laundering (APG) rated the country’s effectiveness low both for 
the regulator, the Royal Monetary Authority (RMA), and for financial institutions’ compliance with 
anti-money laundering/combating the financing of terrorism (AML/CFT) requirements.8 The report 
also rated Bhutan noncompliant with technical assessment of risks and in applying a risk-based 
approach because Bhutan continues to use compliance-based bank supervision. Nonperforming

Moreover, because of insufficient oversight and monitoring, there have been reported among

of the University of Oxford has facilitated a self-assessment of cybersecurity capacity in Bhutan. 
While Bhutan may not be threatened by direct, systemic cyberattacks, increasing digitalization 
leaves it open to risk. The country also lacks a data backup and recovery infrastructure for 
business continuity planning.11 
 
8.  Low financial literacy and inadequate financial inclusion. Bhutan’s finance sector has 
been growing rapidly. The ratio of private sector credit to gross domestic product increased from 
15.4% in 2005 to 50.6% in 2018. However, the expansion of private credit has not benefited the 
population evenly. In rural areas, demand for less complex and less time-consuming banking 
services is substantially unmet. Because of their limited exposure to economic opportunities, 
women encounter less-favorable conditions for accessing finance than do men. As of December 
2017, among the 64.5% of adults in Bhutan who held savings accounts, 56.0% were men while 
only 44.0% were women. Only 16.1% of adults had access to credit, of which 64.0% were men 
and 36.0% were women. Similarly, of the 17.0% of adults owning insurance, 59.0% were men 
and 41.0% were women.12 This is partly because banks still assess loan requests against 
collateral, rather than in consideration of a project’s financial viability. On the other hand, banks 
face limited access to credit information, high costs of servicing distant locations, and weaknesses 
in restructuring and insolvency rules. On the deposit side, the small and irregular savings of the 
rural population coupled with poor access to banks mean that many people prefer to keep their 
savings as ready cash. Inadequate knowledge about insurance products impedes their utility. 
Many rural communities lack access to formal remittance services.13 Therefore, the benefits of 
modern electronic and online payment systems have yet to reach all, and cash still dominates the 
payment system.14 
 
9.  Financial inclusion has been improving because of the establishment of microfinance 
institutions, the introduction of digital services, the use of bank agents, the introduction of priority 
sector lending and financial literacy programs, and the imposition of the minimum lending rate in 
2016. However, financial inclusion remains inadequate because of limited access to finance. 
Moreover, there is no consumer protection in Bhutan. Rural borrowers rarely have any means of 
recourse if bank staff act improperly, and attentiveness to customer service appears to be lacking. 
Customers  of  financial  institutions  in  Bhutan  are  poorly  informed  about  their  rights  and 
responsibilities. There is no convenient mechanism for dispute resolution. During focus group 
discussions, some respondents reported that they had trouble resolving discrepancies between

B.  Policy Reform and ADB’s Value Addition 
 
10.  The government’s reform agenda. The program will support the government in its 
commitment to continue reforms to make the finance sector more responsive to emerging 
priorities, while remaining stable and inclusive. This support is critical for the government to 
achieve  national  key  result  areas  of  the  Twelfth  Five  Year  Plan,  2018–2023,  such  as 
macroeconomic  stability,  economic  diversification,  and  poverty  reduction  (footnote  3).  The 
government has already prepared several long-term sector development strategies. In 2014, the 
RMA  formulated  the  Capital  Market  Master  Plan  for  Bhutan,  2014–2024,  which  provides 
additional financial intermediation sources, including microfinance intermediaries that can serve 
as alternatives to commercial banks, on which Bhutan had previously depended.15 In 2017, the 
government approved the Financial Sector Development Action Plan, which details reform actions 
that affect, among others, the banking system, nonbank financial institutions, and financial 
inclusion and financial literacy.16 Since 2017, the RMA has established several payment system 
infrastructures through regulatory reforms and system automation. In July 2019, the government 
launched the e-commerce guidelines and platform, and revised its foreign direct investment policy 
and cottage and small industry policy. The RMA adopted Macro Prudential Regulations in 2018. 
In 2019, the RMA issued risk management guidelines to provide minimum standards for risk 
management practices and to encourage financial institutions to adopt and implement a sound 
risk management framework. The RMA also approved the establishment of the Rural Enterprise 
Development Corporation Limited, which will be the first cottage and small industry bank to 
operate in Bhutan. It will be a specialized bank that will service the financing needs of cottage and 
small industries. 
 
11.  Policy reforms. The proposed program modality is a programmatic approach. It consists 
of  two  subprograms  that  are  designed  to  allow  ADB  to  remain  engaged  and  to  help  the 
government implement increasingly complex long-term finance sector reforms. Each subprogram 
is a single tranche intervention. To supplement these, there is a post-program engagement 
framework that will guide the design of the reforms under a third subprogram. There are 9 policy 
actions under subprogram 1, and 13 policy actions under subprogram 2. These policy actions are 
designed to achieve three reform areas: (i) nonbank financial system developed, (ii) stability and 
integrity of the financial system strengthened, and (iii) financial inclusion promoted. These are 
presented in detail in the government’s Development Policy Letter (Appendix 3) and the Policy 
Matrix (Appendix 4).  
 
12.  Reform area 1: Nonbank financial system developed. This reform area is designed to 
develop medium-term and long-term debt instruments and to deepen the nonbank financial 
system.  Under  subprogram  1,  the  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF)  approved  both  a  long-term 
government bond issuance strategy and an implementation plan. Under subprogram 2, the MOF 
will  develop  rules  and  regulations  for  government  bond  issuance.  The  government  has 
established a committee to assess its present rules on issuing corporate bonds and commercial 
papers to help develop the domestic bond market.17 Introducing long-term debt instruments with 
an  established  yield  curve  will  establish  a  much-needed  benchmark  rate  for  long-dated

16 Government of Bhutan, Royal Monetary Authority. Financial Sector Development Strategy Action Plan. Unpublished. 
17 The government has adopted the Capital Market Master Plan, 2014–2024 that includes a debt market strategy and

instruments and provide long-term investment outlets for insurance companies and the NPPF. 
Under subprogram 1, the government approved a national policy for the NPPF. That policy 
creates sustainable and inclusive pension and provident fund schemes by expanding membership 
coverage to include private sector and self-employed individuals, consequently benefiting women 
who constitute 61% of self-employed individuals.18 Under subprogram 2, the government will 
approve (i) a strategy for the expansion of coverage to these excluded groups, and (ii) rules and 
regulations for implementing the NPPF policy. In parallel under subprogram 1, the RMA issued a 
directive to assess the solvency of insurance companies  based on how they comply  with 
prudential regulations. Under subprogram 2, the government plans to amend the Financial 
Services Act to allow insurance companies to introduce more insurance products, and thereby 
diversify their portfolios and minimize risks. With respect to housing finance, the government 
drafted  a  National  Human  Settlement  Policy  in  2015  and  conducted  a  housing  finance 
consultation in 2016. Consequently, ADB completed a feasibility study for housing finance reform 
in February 2018. Under subprogram 1, the government used ADB’s feasibility study in drafting 
its  National  Housing  Policy,  which  emphasizes  housing  affordability,  and  which  helps 
disadvantaged  groups,  including  women,  to  access  housing  finance.  Subsequently,  under 
subprogram 2, the government will establish a detailed strategy that will define fiscal measures 
and incentives, and that will identify the housing finance mechanisms to be used. Over the long 
term, this will help the government establish a housing finance entity as a nonbank financial 
institution.19 
 
13.  Reform area 2: Stability and integrity of the financial system strengthened. This 
reform area is designed to strengthen the banking and financial infrastructure and to provide for 
effective supervision. To achieve this, the RMA has instituted risk-based bank supervision, 
including  stress  testing,  and  has  designed  templates  for  institutional  risk  profiles  and  risk 
assessment. Under subprogram 1, the RMA has begun to implement provisioning for impaired 
loans to comply with the Bhutan Accounting Standards. The RMA will revise its Prudential 
Regulations to comply with the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS).20 Under 
subprogram 1, the government enacted the Anti-Money Laundering and Combating the Financing 
of Terrorism Act 2018. The RMA approved AML/CFT Rules and Regulations 2018. These reforms 
have improved Bhutan’s technical compliance with the Recommendations of the Financial Action 
Task Force on Money Laundering, as noted in APG’s follow-up report to the APG’s 2016 mutual 
evaluation report on Bhutan.21 The follow-up report also upgraded the country’s rating from 
noncompliant to largely compliant in technically assessing risks and using a risk-based approach. 
Under subprogram 2, the RMA will operationalize an online anti-money laundering reporting 
system. Similarly, in April 2019 under subprogram 1, the RMA issued a directive on implementing 
a cybersecurity framework. Under subprogram 2, the RMA will adopt a business continuity plan 
and  a  cybersecurity  framework,  which  will  seek  to  preempt  cyber  threats  proactively. 
Cybersecurity is monitored both by the Bhutan Computer Incident Response Team and by the 
RMA’s Financial Institutions Cyber Response Team. Banks are implementing initiatives to comply 
with the Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard and ISO/IEC 27001:2013 certifications, 
which will enhance cybersecurity controls.

14.  Reform area 3: Financial inclusion promoted. This reform area is designed to promote 
financial  inclusion  and to  enhance financial  literacy  by  focusing  on  disadvantaged groups, 
including the poor, youth, and women. Under subprogram 1, the RMA approved the National 
Financial Inclusion Strategy (NFIS), 2018–2023 and the National Financial Literacy Strategy 
(NFLS),  2018–2023.22 These  strategies  seek  to  improve  the  livelihoods  of  vulnerable  and 
marginalized segments of the population, including women and youth, by enhancing their financial 
literacy and capabilities and by giving them better access to financial services. The RMA also 
approved rules and regulations on consumer protection in connection with financial services to 
empower service users and to enhance consumer confidence. Financial service providers—
comprising  five  banks,  three  insurance  companies,  and  six  microfinance  institutions—will 
consequently establish formal consumer grievance redressal mechanisms under subprogram 2. 
Under subprogram 2, the RMA will expand the curriculum framework that it uses to educate both 
local government officials and students in nonformal education centers and technical training 
institutes, while focusing on women. The TA attached to the program will help the RMA to 
implement the NFIS and NFLS effectively. To do so, under subprogram 2, the RMA will approve 
the action plan for the NFIS and the NFLS. The action plan will widen and intensify access to 
credit, especially among cottage and small industries, which comprise more than 95% of the total 
number of companies and employ significant numbers of women. The action plan will establish 
an  inclusive  green  finance  scheme  that  will  help  to  finance  entrepreneurs  who  invest  in 
environment-friendly projects. To promote access to credit by farmers, the government will 
improve commodity trading facilities and establish a warehouse receipt financing scheme that will 
enable farmers to use receipts as collateral. 
 
15,  Post-program engagement framework. The program provides for a structured dialogue 
over 5–10 years on finance sector reforms between ADB, the MOF, and the RMA. Key activities 
under  the  program  that  require  further  dialogue  to  promote  sustainability  include  (i)  the 
government’s issuance of domestic long-term bonds; (ii) the strategy and implementation plan for 
affordable housing, including measures to address women’s constraints in accessing housing 
finance; (iii) the risk profiling and assessment of all commercial banks; (iv) consumer protection; 
and (v) timely implementation of the NFIS and NFLS. A third subprogram may be proposed 
depending on the positive outcome of subprograms 1 and 2. 
 
16.  ADB’s experience. ADB has been a partner in Bhutan’s development since 1982. The 
Bhutan–ADB partnership in the finance sector began in 1984 with the provision of the Industrial 
Sector Study and the Establishment of a Development Financing Mechanism TA project. 23  This 
subsequently helped the government to establish the Bhutan Development Finance Corporation, 
now  called  Bhutan  Development  Bank  Limited.  ADB  was  also  instrumental  in  helping  to 
strengthen the RMA’s central banking role as the single regulator of banks and nonbanks under 
the Financial Institution Act in 1992.24 This gave the RMA independence to determine monetary 
policy. To support the RMA, ADB also helped to establish the Credit Information Bureau in 2009, 
the Accounting and Auditing Standards Board of Bhutan in 2010, and the Financial Intelligence 
Unit for AML/CFT in 2011. Subsequently, Bhutan has been continually reforming its finance 
sector, which has consequently deepened and expanded at about 14% annually in terms of 
assets on average from December 2014 to December 2018. This underlines the government’s 
commitment to reform. The Independent Evaluation Department’s validation report of the country 
partnership strategy final review, 2014–2018 noted that, throughout its operations in Bhutan, ADB

17.  Lessons.  The  program  has  drawn  on  lessons  from  ADB’s  previous  policy-based 
programs that supported finance sector reforms, such as the first and the second Strengthening 
Economic  Management  Program,  which  helped  the  government  implement  key  reforms  to 
develop the financial market and strengthen financial capacity.26 The design of the proposed 
program is also based on achievements and lessons from ongoing TA projects.27 Many of the 
reform actions are continuations of reforms that ADB supported previously. For example, the 
stress testing that began under the second Strengthening Economic Management Program has 
been expanded and intensified under this program. Financial literacy, also started under the 
second Strengthening Economic Management Program, is further promoted under this program. 
Bhutan has continued AML/CFT reforms since receiving its mutual evaluation report in 2016. The 
program also supports the RMA’s efforts to comply fully with the remaining recommendations 
through ongoing ADB TA projects (footnote 27). Although the MOF has been issuing short-term 
treasury bills since 2009, this program seeks to deepen the market by introducing a long-term 
bond that extends the maturity of existing instruments. Bhutan has been complying in phases with 
IFRS standards and plans to comply fully by 2021.  
 
18.  The reform actions under the program have been prepared to help the government realize 
its current capacity to improve cybersecurity in Bhutan. The Global Cyber Security Capacity 
Centre of the University of Oxford has suggested that the government should collaborate with 
industry and civil society to promote cybersecurity and thereby encourage information and 
communication technology development. The Independent Evaluation Department validation 
report noted that efforts to diversify the economy cannot be sustained without accompanying 
public sector management and finance reforms that strengthen governance (footnote 1). 
 
19.  ADB’s value addition to the program. ADB’s value addition has been to support the 
government’s reform agenda through a strategic framework; informed policy dialogue; evidence-
based studies; and sequencing and pacing of reforms, particularly in planning and coordinating 
various elements of reforms. ADB also supports capacity building, including preparation of 
blueprints for specific reform actions, and the promotion of ownership among stakeholders, 
including the private sector. The “One ADB” approach has been implemented more effectively 
since 2017 when ADB’s Bhutan Resident Mission expanded and undertook core tasks in country 
operations.  The  greater  field  presence  and  staff  strength  have  enabled  ADB  to  be  more 
responsive to client needs and emerging issues in coordination with ADB experts from the South 
Asia  Department  and  other  departments,  including  the  Economic  Research  and  Regional 
Coordination Department; Office of Anticorruption and Integrity; Office of the General Counsel; 
Office of Public–Private Partnership; Office of Risk Management; Procurement, Portfolio and 
Financial  Management  Department;  Private  Sector  Operations  Department;  Treasury 
Department; and Sustainable Development and Climate Chance Department. 
 
                                                
25 Independent Evaluation Department. 2019. Validation of the Country Partnership Strategy Final Review, 2014–2018 
in Bhutan. Manila: ADB. 
26 ADB. 2015. Completion Report: Strengthening Economic Management Program in Bhutan. Manila; and ADB. 2018. 
Completion Report: Strengthening Economic Management Program II in Bhutan. Manila. 
27 ADB.  2012.  Technical  Assistance  to  the  Kingdom  of  Bhutan  for  Enhancing  Development  Management  for

8 
20.  Development partner coordination. The involvement of development partners in the 
finance sector is well defined.28 The design of the proposed reforms is informed by a number of 
studies supported by ADB and other development partners. Access to credit was identified as 
one of the major critical development constraints in a diagnostic study on Bhutan that ADB 
prepared with the Government of Australia and the Japan International Cooperation Agency.29 
The government adopted its Capital Market Master Plan in 2014 following ADB TA that created, 
among others, a blueprint for a debt market strategy.30 The World Bank created the Financial 
Sector Development Action Plan for Bhutan, which was approved by the government in 2017. 
Also in 2017, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) established the South Asia Regional Training 
and Technical Assistance Center for economic capacity building in New Delhi. The IMF is helping 
the government set up a liquidity forecasting framework. This aligns with the goal of moving the 
conduct of monetary policy from direct to indirect monetary instruments. 
 
C.  Impacts of the Reform 
 
21.  The impact of the reform will be the improved economic welfare of the Bhutanese people, 
especially  women,  through  increased  employment,  private  sector  business  development, 
enhanced access to finance, and greater efficiency of financial intermediation. The program will 
support the government with institutional reforms  while improving the technical capacity of 
regulatory and financial institutions. The first reform area of this program seeks to develop the 
nonbank financial system by issuing both a long-term government bond and corporate bonds. 
This will increase the volume of bonds traded in the capital market. By 2023, the total value of 
outstanding bonds is expected to reach Nu9.3 billion (about $130 million), an increase of 7% from 
the 2018 baseline. The second reform area aims to strengthen the stability of the financial system. 
This will further increase the year-on-year growth of private sector credit provided by commercial 
banks. The program’s target for this is to increase the average 2014–2018 baseline rate of 14.7% 
to at least an average of 17.0% for 2019–2023. The third reform area is to promote financial 
inclusion by implementing the NFIS and the NFLS. This will improve the private sector’s access 
to finance. The target is for the percentage of adults who have access to credit to reach at least 
18.0% by 2023 compared with the 16.0% baseline of 2018. 
 
D.  Development Financing Needs and Budget Support 
 
22.  The total expenditure for the Twelfth Five Year Plan, 2018–2023 is estimated at Nu310 
billion (about $4.3 billion), an increase of 38% from that of the previous 5-year plan. Of the total 
expenditure, current expenditure accounts for 62.5%, or Nu193.90 billion (about $2.7 billion), all 
of which is financed by domestic revenue. Capital expenditure accounts for 37.5%, or Nu116.12 
billion (about $1.6 billion), 21% of which is financed by domestic revenue. Domestic revenue thus 
finances roughly 70%, or Nu218.16 billion (about $3.1 billion), of total expenditure. Financing is 
required to fund the remaining 79% of capital expenditure. Of capital expenditure, 54% will be 
financed through grants. The final 25% of capital expenditure will be financed by external 
borrowings from multilateral development partners, mainly from ADB and the World Bank, on 
highly concessional terms. The external financing gap over the 5-year period is estimated at Nu29 
billion (about $406 million). 
 
23.  The government has requested a loan of $30 million from ADB’s concessional ordinary 
capital resources to help finance subprogram 1. The loan will have a 24-year term, including a 
                                                
28 Development Coordination (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
29 ADB. 2013. Bhutan: Critical Development Constraints. Manila. 
30 ADB. 2012. Technical Assistance to the Kingdom of Bhutan for Capital Market Development. Manila.

9 
grace period of 8 years; an interest rate of 1.0% per year during the grace period and 1.5% per 
year thereafter; and such other terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan agreement. The 
indicative loan amount for subprogram 2 is $30 million from ADB’s concessional ordinary capital 
resources. Bhutan was assessed to have a moderate risk in the 2018 IMF–World Bank debt 
sustainability assessment. The IMF assessment letter provides current assessment of Bhutan’s 
macroeconomic conditions, prospects, and policies (Appendix 2). 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
24.  The MOF is the executing agency, and the RMA and the Ministry of Works and Human 
Settlement are implementing agencies. A steering committee, chaired by the secretary of the 
MOF, was established for guiding and monitoring the program implementation. The proceeds of 
the policy-based loan will be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Loan Disbursement Handbook 
(2017, as amended from time to time). The implementation period is January 2018–November 
2019 for subprogram 1, and December 2019–March 2022 for subprogram 2. ADB will support the 
government in implementing the post-program engagement framework to promote sustainable 
outcomes. All subprogram 1 policy actions were accomplished. 
 
III.  ATTACHED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
25.  The TA is estimated to cost $525,000 of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-6). The TA will be implemented over 27 
months from December 2019 to March 2022 to support financial inclusion activities and post-
program  engagement  activities.  It  will  require  a  total  of  12  person-months  of  international 
consultancy  services  and  14  person-months  of  national  consultancy  services.  Individual 
consultants will be engaged. The TA will assist in (i) preparing regulatory frameworks and 
background analyses; (ii) building the capacity of government agencies and financial institutions 
to implement reforms; and (iii) raising the financial literacy levels of disadvantaged groups, 
including women and youth. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of 
counterpart staff, office and housing accommodation, office supplies, secretarial assistance, 
domestic  transportation,  and  other  in-kind  contributions.  Consultants  will  be  recruited  in 
accordance  with  the  ADB  Procurement  Policy  (2017  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  All 
disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
IV.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
26.  Safeguards. The program does not trigger ADB’s safeguards policies and is classified 
category C for environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples.31 
 
27.  Poverty  and  social.  Bhutan’s  limited  financial  market  development  has  had  a 
disproportionate impact on the poor. Only 25% of adults in the poorest 40% of households in 
Bhutan have a bank account while in other developing economies the rate is 50% based on 2014 
data.32 Also, as of December 2017, although 64.5% of adults in Bhutan had a savings account, 
only 6.1% had access to credit, and 17.8% held a life insurance policy (footnote 12). Insufficient 
access to affordable credit and other financial services, coupled with low financial literacy and a 
lack of consumer protection mechanisms, constrains the ability of the poor to improve their lives. 
Reforms under the program will help the government achieve its poverty reduction target by 
                                                
31 Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2) 
32 Government of Bhutan, Royal Monetary Authority. 2018. National Financial Inclusion Strategy 2018-2023. Thimphu.

10 
providing  the  poor  greater  access  to  financial  services.  The  program  also  includes  the 
development of lending covenants for housing and homeownership, and introduction of risk-
sharing arrangements to help expand access to credit. The program objectives and activities also 
align with the goal of advancing gender equality and empowering women by improving women’s 
access to financial resources. The government will monitor the progress of how women increase 
their access to credit, accrue savings, obtain insurance, and receive pensions, and will report to 
ADB as part of its continuing policy dialogue. 
 
28.  Governance. Bhutan’s inherent financial management risk is considered moderate. The 
2016 public expenditure and financial accountability assessment reported improvements from the 
previous assessment (2010).33 However, the lowest scores were given  for accounting and 
reporting, government transparency, and budget reliability. Consequently, the government is 
implementing a public finance management reform action plan that covers five reform measures, 
of which two measures have yet to be implemented: (i) integration of the civil services information 
system with the payroll system, and (ii) integration of the planning and monitoring system with the 
multiyear rolling budget system and the public expenditure management system. In terms of 
corruption, Bhutan consistently scores high on global indexes for control of corruption, ranking 
25th out of 180 countries in Transparency International’s 2018 Corruption Perception Index. The 
domestic perception of corruption, however, has been worsening. ADB’s Anticorruption Policy 
(1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed with the government and the MOF. 
 
29.  Risks and mitigating measures. Major risks and mitigating measures are described in 
detail in the risk assessment and risk management plan.34 
 
V.  ASSURANCES 
 
30.  The government has assured ADB that implementation of the program shall conform to 
all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, safeguards, 
gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail in the loan 
agreement.  
 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
31.  I am satisfied that the proposed programmatic approach and policy-based loan would 
comply with the Articles of Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend 
that the Board approve 
(i)  the programmatic approach for the Financial Market Development Program; and 
(ii)  the loan of $30,000,000 to the Kingdom of Bhutan for the Financial Market 
Development Program, from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, in concessional 
terms, with an interest charge at the rate of 1.0% per year during the grace period 
and 1.5% per year thereafter; for a term of 24 years, including a grace period of 8 
years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with 
those set forth in the draft loan agreement presented to the Board. 
 
Takehiko Nakao 
President
